relevant_history: Kristen uses Miro religiously — she builds affinity maps with sticky notes after every interview round, which she actually enjoys but admits takes half a day per project. She's good at synthesis but the time cost is brutal at agency pace. Her clients want findings in 48 hours; her process takes 72.
emotional_baseline: Competent and methodical by nature, but the volume of concurrent projects has her looking for shortcuts without feeling like she's cutting corners.
in_their_voice: The affinity mapping works great, I just can't spend four hours doing it for every client project when I have three others waiting.

name: Ernest Morris
occupation: Product Manager
life_stage: PM at a 200-person Series B company in the HR tech space. He runs a squad of 8 and has to get executive sign-off before any major feature work, which means his research findings need to be bulletproof in the boardroom.
relevant_history: Ernest does structured interviews with a Google Doc template he built himself, which keeps things organized. The problem is synthesis — he ends up with 8 docs full of notes and no clean way to see what cut across all of them. He spends Sunday nights turning interview notes into a one-pager for Monday's product review, which he resents.
emotional_baseline: Organized and disciplined, but frustrated that the last mile — the actual synthesis — always eats his weekend and still feels imprecise.
in_their_voice: I can run the interviews fine, it's pulling everything together into something leadership will actually trust that kills me every time.

name: Sandra Zimmerman
occupation: Head of Product
life_stage: Head of product at a bootstrapped e-commerce software company with 25 people. She manages two junior PMs and sets the research agenda for the whole product org, but resources are tight and there's no dedicated researcher.
relevant_history: Sandra has the most structured approach on the team — she built a research repository in Airtable two years ago that she still updates sporadically. In practice though, her junior PMs just dump notes into a shared Google Drive folder and she synthesizes by reading through everything herself before quarterly planning. It works, but it doesn't scale.
emotional_baseline: Pragmatic and slightly tired of being the person who has to make sense of everyone else's notes — she's looking for something she can hand off or speed up.
in_their_voice: We technically have a research process, I just end up being the one who has to read everything and figure out what it all means anyway.

name: Jordan Suarez
occupation: Product Manager
life_stage: PM at a remote-first startup building dev tools, Series A with 35 people. His team moves fast and he's expected to run continuous discovery — interviews, surveys, support ticket analysis — on top of regular sprint work.
relevant_history: Jordan records calls on Grain and loves the highlight feature, but his highlight library has become a graveyard of 200 clips he never goes back to. He pastes a few choice quotes into Slack when he wants to make a point, but his synthesis is basically vibes at this point. He's never had time to build a real system.
emotional_baseline: Enthusiastic about research in theory, a bit sheepish about the gap between his intentions and his actual process.
in_their_voice: I have hundreds of Grain highlights and zero actual insights — I keep collecting stuff and never doing anything with it.

name: Erin Edwards
occupation: Design Lead
life_stage: Design lead at a growth-stage company (150 people, pre-IPO) that sells marketing software. She manages a team of 4 designers and is the informal research lead because the company keeps promising to hire a researcher and hasn't.
relevant_history: Erin runs research by committee — she and her designers each take notes during interviews in whatever format they prefer, then she tries to synthesize across all their docs in a two-hour working session. It's collaborative but chaotic: everyone notices different things and there's no consistent format. She ends up doing the real synthesis alone after everyone leaves.
emotional_baseline: Good-humored about the chaos but increasingly frustrated that her team's collective research effort produces less clarity than it should.
in_their_voice: We do all this research together as a team and I still end up in a room alone at 9pm trying to figure out what we actually learned.

name: Jonathan Lawrence
occupation: Founder / CEO
life_stage: Second-time founder, seed stage, building a vertical SaaS tool for independent insurance brokers. He's done this before but still doing customer discovery himself because he doesn't want to hire sales until he's sure the ICP is right.
relevant_history: Jonathan is a good interviewer — he knows how to ask open questions and let people talk. His problem is downstream: he takes detailed voice memos after every call while driving, transcribes them sporadically, and has no consistent home for any of it. He tries to pattern-match across calls in his head, which worked for 10 interviews but is breaking down at 40.
emotional_baseline: Confident and self-aware, he knows exactly what his process gap is — he just hasn't found a fix that doesn't feel like more work than it saves.
in_their_voice: I'm a pretty good listener, I just have no idea what to do with everything I'm hearing once the call ends.

name: Christine Fisher
occupation: Chief of Staff
life_stage: Chief of staff at a 60-person Series B company. She's technically not in product but she owns the voice-of-customer function and is responsible for synthesizing user feedback and presenting it to the executive team quarterly.
relevant_history: Christine pulls feedback from three sources — NPS comments, support tickets, and quarterly interviews — and manually themes everything in a Google Sheet. She color-codes rows by topic, which her CEO loves, but it takes her two full days to build each quarter. She's started wondering if this is even the right way to do it but doesn't know what else to try.
emotional_baseline: Meticulous and earnest, she puts real effort into this work but has started to feel like the effort-to-insight ratio is off and there must be a better way.
in_their_voice: Two days to build a color-coded spreadsheet that my CEO spends 10 minutes looking at — there has to be a smarter way to do this.

name: Bethany Fisher
occupation: Founder / CEO
life_stage: Solo founder of a bootstrapped wellness app, 2 years in, about 3,000 paying users. She does all her user research herself and treats it as her competitive edge — she talks to users constantly but struggles to turn conversations into product direction.
relevant_history: Bethany has a ritual: she blocks two hours after every batch of interviews to write a reflection doc in Notion where she free-writes what she heard. It's personally useful but not very shareable, and when she brings in contractors or advisors she can't easily hand them the synthesis. She's aware her process is idiosyncratic and only works because she has it all in her head.
emotional_baseline: Thoughtful and intentional about research but quietly anxious that her understanding of her users lives only inside her own head and would be hard to hand off.
in_their_voice: I talk to users all the time and I feel like I understand them, but if someone asked me to prove it I'm not sure I could show them anything concrete.

name: Michelle Maldonado
occupation: Product Manager
life_stage: Senior PM at a large enterprise software company (2,000+ employees) embedded in a smaller product unit that operates somewhat autonomously. She has more resources than a startup PM but still runs scrappy research because getting the formal UX research team involved takes months.
relevant_history: Michelle has learned to route around her company's research bureaucracy — she books her own interviews, takes notes in a Word doc (company standard), and builds her own themes deck in PowerPoint without waiting for the official process. She's fast and effective but chronically undersupported, and her decks take longer to make than they should because she's pulling everything together manually.
emotional_baseline: Resourceful and a bit wry about the irony of doing fast scrappy research inside a slow enterprise — she's made her peace with it but still wants her DIY process to be less painful.
in_their_voice: By the time the official research team could help me, my sprint is already done — so I just do it myself, badly, on a deadline.
